      • literalToLowerCase

        @Nullable
public static String literalToLowerCase(@Nullable
                                                  String s)
        Converts a string to lower case in a locale insensitive manner, and can accept null input strings. Returns null when input is null. The string conversion uses String.toLowerCase(Locale.ENGLISH). See String.toLowerCase() on when to use the default system locale during conversion to lower case, and in which cases this will produce the wrong results.
        Parameters:
        s - Input string, or null.
        Returns:
        String converted to lower case, or null.

      • toCodePoints

        @Nonnull
public static int[] toCodePoints(@Nonnull
                                          String s)
        Converts a string to a list of Unicode code points. This method should be used when wanting to iterate over a string character-by-character. This method is necessary because Java stores characters as UTF-16 values in a String, and String.charAt(int) returns a 16-bit value. This works fine for characters in the Basic Multilingual Plane (BMP), but Unicode allows for supplementary characters that take up more than 16 bits to represent them. For Strings, this means that Java will store those characters as two characters, with the first character being a value in the high-surrogates range, and the second value in the low-surrogates range. Therefore, charAt(n) may actually return a char value that does not represent the actual character when a supplementary character is stored, and only combining charAt(n) together with charAt(n plus 1) would result in the correct character. The implementation of this method is based on JDK-5003547 and JDK-5063163. See Character and Supplementary Characters in the Java Platform for further information on Java and Unicode.
        Parameters:
        s - Input string.
        Returns:
        Array of all code points contained in-order in s. The length of the returned array is <= the length of the given s.

      • mkString

        @Nonnull
public static String mkString(@Nonnull
                                       String separator,
                                       @Nonnull
                                       Collection<?> values)
        Assembles a String with all the elements of an input collection using a provided separator. Example: 
              final List<Integer> list = new ArrayList<Integer>();
      list.add(1);
      list.add(2);
      list.add(3);
        Calling mkString as shown below: 
              final String result = mkString("|", list);
        will provide: 
              result := "1|2|3"
        Parameters:
        values - Values.
        separator - Separator string between values.
        Returns:
        String with values, separated by separator.
